history.content:
I got an A+ in 16B when I took it in Fa19 (im probably in the small minority where I love 16B and going to pursue EE). I didn't have any circuits background except for 16A and I did take 54 as well so I can offer you some perspective of a Math 54 -> 16B student. 

When I helped out in homework parties this semester, it was very obvious when a student did Math 54 -> 16B because they would struggle A LOT in understanding new 16B circuit/controls concepts. 16B assumes you have a solid understanding of circuits parts from 16A and moves pretty fast to cover new material. Thus, I would always advise people to take 16A -> 16B instead of Math 54 -> 16B because instead of cramming Module 2 in 16A in the summer or during the semester, you can take it at a slower pace if you take 16A over the semester.

So 16B's 1st homework is always the 16A final from the previous semester. If you happen to struggle A LOT on doing this part, I would seriously recommend taking 16A before 16B. You can push through but after the 1st homework, you are expected to be comfortable with these concepts: 

1. Nodal Analysis (includes KCL, KVL, V-R relationships). The single most important concept from 16A is HEAVILY used in 16B. Even if it's just used in Module 1 in 16B, it shows up in filter designs, robotics, and new and interesting exam questions where they integrate multiple concepts together and nodal analysis is ALWAYS there and expected of you to use and understand. 

2. Buffers/Op-Amps. Used a lot in filter designs and you're expected to know this in and out. A great check you can do is in one of the 16A discussions, they give you a "circuit cookbook" with all the formulas of the different op-amp configurations. If you can derive every single formula on that sheet (I think theres only 6) with relative ease, you're good to go in 16B. 

3. Applications of Linear Algebra. You are in the slight advantage here where I think 54 does a much better job at teaching linear algebra concepts than 16A, probably because its not as rushed. However, 16A's linear algebra is taught in a different perspective than 54. 54 approaches it from a theoretical approach but 16A teaches from an application approach. So the learning curve here won't be too tough, but it doesn't hurt to go through Module 3 of 16A in addition to Module 2 (very easy for you to pick up since you took 54). Least squares and OMP are very important concepts 16B uses for Outlier Removal, Upper Triangulation, Classification and many more applications and its HELPFUL for you to think of 54 concepts in that perspective before you take the class. 

General tips for 16B apart from the things you're expected to pick up I wrote above: 

1. Discussions are your best friends. The concepts and applications taught in lectures are extremely dense and something you probably have never seen before. Discussions help condense that information and brings in some math for you to see the concepts taught in lecture. I recommend Nick's/Ramsey's discussions as I think they are awesome teachers. 

2. Practice is key. The exams are hard, non-intuitive and requires a lot of thinking. Intuition in this class built through 1-2 key concepts through each module. If you understand those 1-2 key concepts, you are going to do well in the class. People often to struggle to see the concepts when studying/taking exams and default to memorisation which doesn't work in 16B. For example (you probably won't understand this now but when you take the class you will see it), they teach you to solve simple diff. eq but then they teach you diagonalization as a change of basis much later. If you see the connection on how diagonalising helps you reduce a harder problem to the simple diff eq you learnt in the beginning, you're set for this topic as most students don't see this connection. 

Let me know if you have more questions

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

One piece of advice to all students who feel uncomfortable about circuit analysis: Treat circuit analysis as a process of applying a set of mathematical rules. At least at the level of EECS16A/B, circuit analysis is simply a result of graph or network theory, which can all be cast into a simple linear expression $$Ax-b$$, where x represents the voltage and $$b$$ is the current/voltage source. Specifically, after assigning polarity to each current, the circuit is just a directed graph and is described by an incident matrix $$A$$. Selecting a reference node is the same as eliminating one linear dependent column in the matrix $$A$$. Ohm's law for the simple circuits taught in 16B is nothing but a linear equation: $$y = G(Ax-b)$$, where $$G$$ is a matrix with all the conductances stored on the diagonal and y is the current. KCL or KVL are extra constraints on the linear equation: $$A^T y = 0$$. The techniques you are taught in 16B has nothing to do with physics, so don't be intimidated.

I know lots of CS students probably don't have the incentive to learn circuits, so let me show you an interesting perspective: One common practice in engineering is to convert a problem into a minimization problem with some constraints. If you combine all the equations I mentioned above, you will get $$A^T G A x = A^T G b$$, you immediately realize that this is the normal equation for weighted least squares. Inspired by the fact that least square is also an optimization problem, we convert the normal equation into a quadratic program: $$min \frac{1}{2} y^{T} G^{-1} y - b^T y$$ subject to $$A^Ty = 0$$. The first term of the quadratic cost function is precisely the total power dissipated by the network (ignore the 1/2) if you have a current source. (If you take EECS127 later, you will learn that every optimization problem also has a dual problem. Surprisingly, the dual problem also minimizes the total power, but this time with a voltage source.) Nature is doing the optimization problem for us, and the circuit theory is just one example. Other optimization problem that is naturally solved including the principle of least action and Fermat's principle. It's true that 16A/B doesn't do a great job of revealing the fascinating essence of the circuit theory, but I do believe the material itself is very beneficial to learn about. The same perspective can be applied to the control part of 16B. They won't tell you that a differential or difference equation also has an adjoint equation (think about it as the transpose of the equation); moreover, solving the adjoint equation is the same as the idea of backpropagation for a neural network, which is equivalent to dynamic programming.

I got an A+ in 16B when I took it in Fa19 (im probably in the small minority where I love 16B and going to pursue EE). I didn't have any circuits background except for 16A and I did take 54 as well so I can offer you some perspective of a Math 54 -> 16B student.

2. Buffers/Op-Amps. Used a lot in filter designs and you're expected to know this in and out. A great check you can do is in one of the 16A discussions, they give you a "circuit cookbook" with all the formulas of the different op-amp configurations. If you understand those 1-2 key concepts, you are going to do well in the class. People often to struggle to see the concepts when studying/taking exams and default to memorisation which doesn't work in 16B. For example (you probably won't understand this now but when you take the class you will see it), they teach you to solve simple diff. eq but then they teach you diagonalization as a change of basis much later. If you see the connection on how diagonalising helps you reduce a harder problem to the simple diff eq you learnt in the beginning, you're set for this topic as most students don't see this connection. 

Let me know if you have more questions

Hi
I am intended L&S cs major and I just took math 54 last semester. I am planning to take eecs 16b next Fall or Spring. I have been self studying circuits parts from 16A, but since I have no background for circuits, it’s hard for me to keep up with the materials. This make me worried about doing 16b in the future... 

any advice/tips from people who  took eecs16b after math 54 alone would be appreciated!

 Thank you
history.subject: tips for preparing for EECS 16B
